content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: For me, while many of these kinds of puzzles already exist, I think that it is suitable to be accepted and was a very big challenge for me. Congratulations! This puzzle is getting approved!
If you can illustrate the construction of obstacles with images or short animations, it would make understanding easier.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: There are plenty of pathfinding puzzles on CG but the variable dimension count makes this puzzle different enough to justify it.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Really fun puzzle that's difficult to visualize but not too difficult to implement. It really tests your BFS skills :)
i just learn the A* algorithm... i think this puzzle looks good to apply it

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

This one is definitly hard, because anything more than 3D is so difficult to imagine. I have not tried it, but it seems you have at least kept the problem space small enough, so it should be possible to find a solution without needing a too sophisticated algorithm.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Phew! This was a tricky one in C#. C# doesn't do Array <=> Tuple very well and does not iterate over the members of a tuple. When I tried to make my own multidimensional point type anything over 4 dimensions was too slow. I had to resort to dynamic typing and writing routines to go between arrays and runtime length tuples but in the end, I was able to pass all tests.

Goal
* Consider inserting blank lines between paragraphs for easier reading.

* Consider changing "travel in" to "explore".

* Please change "a n-dimensional" to "an n-dimensional".

* Please replace "To represent the space, your are given its length in every dimension, and the obstacles as 2 opposite points of a n-dimensional rectangle." with:

You are given the size of the space in each dimension and a list of obstacles, each defined by two opposite corners of an axis-aligned n-dimensional hyperrectangle.

(Note: "Rectangle" is not the correct term in higher dimensions. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperrectangle )

* Please add this clarification:
Valid coordinate values in each dimension range from 0 to size of that dimension - 1.

* "the intersecting area remains an obstacle" may be confusing, as "area" usually implies two dimensions. Consider changing it to:

the intersections remain obstacles

* Example:
  • Please add a blank line below the second instance of "z=0   z=1   z=2", the same as you did for the first instance.

  • Please change "the following one (path cells are numbered from 0 to 7):" to:

    shown below, with each step numbered from 0 (start) to 7 (destination).

  • The input specifies the start position as 1,2,0 and the destination as 2,0,0, but the illustrations show the start at 2,1,0 and the destination at 0,2,0. The depicted obstacles do not match the input either.

Input
* Please change "inferior to" to "less than or equal to".

* Please remove the remark in parentheses.

Output
* Please delete "going".

* Please add ", or {{NO PATH}} if no such path exists".

Constraints
* Please add a constraint stating whether starting position and destination can be located inside obstacles.

Cover picture
* Consider uploading a cover picture for the puzzle.

Thanks.

I agree that it's a total mess to visualize (building the testcases was a nightmare lol). But any BFS should do the trick (that's why I had to keep it so small, a 10 cells sided cube in 8D is already 10^8 cells in total). I think it's not too hard for anyone who knows basic pathfinding algorithm. It's just one tweak away from the classic 2D solution.

Goal
* "a wall at position x=1, with only one free cell (1,0,1)": It should be y=1 and one free cell (0,1,1) instead.

Thanks.
